titlealts.searchtitle: HP Helion OpenStack(R) 1.1: Installation: Deploy and Configure HP StoreVirtual VSA

p.b: This document describes the installation process for HP Helion OpenStack(R) 1.1 and HP Helion OpenStack(R) 1.1.1.

body.p: (If you already have 1.1 installed, you can update Helion OpenStack(R) from 1.1 to 1.1.1 by following the update procedures described in HP Helion OpenStack(R) 1.1.1 Update Guide.)
This page provides detailed instructions on deployment of HP StoreVirtual VSA Storage Nodes, and their configuration as Cinder backend. It covers the following topics:

li.xref: Installing HP StoreVirtual VSA Centralized Management Console (CMC) on Linux
Deploying HP StoreVirtual VSA storage sytems
Creating and adding a StoreVirtual Cluster to a new Management Group
Adding a StoreVirtual node to an existing Management Group

section.title: Installing HP StoreVirtual VSA Centralized Management Console (CMC) on Linux
section.p: In order to configure the HP StoreVirtual VSA nodes, you must first install the CMC. You can manage all connected StoreVirtual VSA instances from single CMC connected to HP Helion OpenStack(R) management network.

section.title: Prerequisites

li.p: You must be running the X Windows System to install the CMC.

We recommend that you install CMC on the same KVM host that is used to run the seed VM. This host has direct network connectivity to servers running HP StoreVirtual VSA. However, you may select an alternate host as long as it is accessible from the HP Helion OpenStack(R) management network.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: Ensure the following prerequisites are fulfilled before HP StoreVirtual Storage systems are deployed:

li.p: Ensure that VSA host nodes boot from the local disk. If it boots from the remote disk then ensure that a single path is only enabled.

Ensure that you have created a minimum of two(2) RAID groups. You can create a maximum of eight(8) groups. The first RAID group where the OS image is deployed is not considered for StoreVirtual storage.
Each physical disk should be RAID protected and should not be RAID 0. You can use RAID 5 and above.
For deploying StoreVirtual systems without Adaptive Optimization (AO) the setup must have a minimum two(2) disks(/dev/sda, /dev/sdb).
For deploying StoreVirtual systems with Adaptive Optimization (AO) the setup must have at least three(3) disks(/dev/sda, /dev/sdb, /dev/sdc). The disk /dev/sdb should be a Solid State Drive(SSD).
Ensure that you create the RAID group for SSD drives immediately after creating the RAID group for boot volume. For example: If three RAID groups are to be created. The following is recommended :
Step 1: Create the first RAID group for HDD drives and mark this as boot volume(/dev/sda)
Step 2: Create the second RAID group for SSD drives which should be used as Tier 0 for AO (/dev/sdb)
Step 3: Create the third RAID group for HDD drives which will be used as Tier 1(/dev/sdc)
Seed Cloud is installed and is running.

section.p: The license for the StoreVirtual VSA license is bundled with HP Helion OpenStack(R) and has a maximum limit of 50 TB per node. Hence the total amount of the configured storage on an individual StoreVirtual node should not exceed 50 TB. To extend the 50 TB per node limit, you can add nodes. A VSA cluster can support up to 16 nodes, which means configured storage on a VSA cluster can be as much as 800 TB.

section.p: NOTE: For HP StoreVirtual VSA, a management group with two storage systems and a Failover Manager is the minimum configuration for automated fault tolerant operations. Configurations greater than two systems can be redundant and do not require a Failover Manager. The Failover Manager is a specialized version of the LeftHand OS software designed to operate as a manager and provide automated failover capability. It runs as a virtual appliance and must be installed on a separate system/VM other than the storage systems in the SAN.

section.title: Verifying StoreVirtual installation status
section.p: To verify that the StoreVirtual storage system is deployed successfully, perform the following checks:

li.p: Log in to the undercloud from seed.
Source stackrc file and list the deployed StoreVirtual nodes.

codeblock.codeph: # source stackrc # heat stack-list # nova list|grep vsa

li.p: Log in to the StoreVirtual system from the seed using the IP address retrieved from the above steps.
Check the log files.
The message "Started VM vsa-hostname" indicates the successful installation of StoreVirtual on the machine.The IP Address of the StoreVirtual storage system can be retrieved from this log file.
To display the status of all the StoreVirtual VMs.
To get more details on the installer logs, check the /var/log/storevirtual-installer.log file.
On successful installation of StoreVirtual VM on Baremetal, go to the Centralized Management Console (CMC) and discover the storage systems.

section.title: Creating a StoreVirtual Cluster and adding it to a new Management Group

ul.li: HP StoreVirtual VSA (one or more) is deployed in the same management network where CMC is installed.

section.p: To create a cluster, do the following:

li.p: Open CMC.
By default, the CMC is configured to discover the StoreVirtual nodes in the subnet in which it is installed. You can manually add the nodes also.

p.xref: CMC Main Page (opens in a new window)

li.p: In the CMC UI, click Find and then click Find Systems from the left panel. Find Systems dialogue box is displayed.

p.xref: Find Systems option (opens in a new window)

li.p: You can choose Add or Find option to search the system. Find option starts searching for the nodes in the same subnet as that of CMC. Add option displays an Enter IP pop-up box to enter the IP of the StoreVirtual system.

Note:To get the details of the HP StoreVirtual VSA IP, log in to StoreVirtual system and check /mnt/state/vsa/vsa_network_config.json file and select the second option, which is listed under "vsa network".

p.xref: Add option (opens in a new window)
Find option (opens in a new window)

li.p: Click OK to proceed, or click Cancel to cancel the process.The node is discovered and the details are displayed in a tabular format in the Find Systems dialogue box.
(Optional) Click Add in the Find Systems dialogue box to add more nodes.
(Optional) Click Edit in the Find Systems dialogue box to modify the details of the selected node.
(Optional) Click Remove in the Find Systems box to delete a node.
Click Close to return to the Home page. The discovered nodes are displayed under Available Systems option in the left panel.

p.xref: Discovered Nodes Under Available Systems (opens in a new window)

li.p: To add the node to a management group, right-click the node to display a menu and select Add to a New Management Group. Management Groups, Clusters, And Volumes wizard is displayed.

p.xref: Create Management Page (opens in a new window)

li.p: In the Management Group Name box, enter a name for the management group and click Next to display the Add Administrative User page.
Enter the required information for the Administrative user and click Next to display the Management Group Time page.
Synchronize the time manually or using an NTP server and click Next to display the Domain Name Server Configuration page.
Define DNS details and click Next to display the Email Notification Setup page and define SMTP details.
Note: It is optional to enter the details in the above step.
Click Next to display a Wizard in the Create a Cluster page.
Select the cluster type as Standard Cluster from the displayed options and click Next.
In the Cluster Name box, enter the name of the cluster and click Next.
In the Add VIP and Subnet Mask pop-up box, enter the virtual IP and Subnet Mask of the cluster in the respective boxes and click OK. The details are displayed in a tabular format in the page.
Note: Ensure that the Virtual IP (VIP) is unique and is in the same subnet as the HP StoreVirtual VSA system.
Click Next to go to the next page.
(Optional) Click the checkbox displayed against Skip Volume Creation.
Click Next.The Management Group and Cluster is created and displays in the Home page of CMC.

p.xref: CMC Main Page with the Cluster (opens in a new window)

section.title: Adding HP StoreVirtual VSA System to an existing Management Group
section.p: To add a StoreVirtual system to any existing Management Group, do the following:

li.p: Open CMC.
By default, the CMC is configured to discover the HP StoreVirtual VSA systems in the subnet on which it is installed. You can manually add the nodes also.
In the CMC page, click Find Systems from the left panel. Find Systems dialogue box is displayed with an Enter IP pop-up box.
You can choose Add or Find option to search the system. Find option starts searching for the nodes in the subnet. Add option displays an Enter IP pop-up box to enter the IP of the StoreVirtual node.
Click OK to proceed or click Cancel to cancel the process.The node is discovered and the details are displayed in a tabular format in the Find Systems dialogue box.
(Optional) Click Add in the Find Systems dialogue box to add more nodes.
(Optional) Click Edit in the Find Systems dialogue box to modify the details of the selected node.
(Optional) Click Remove in the Find Systems box to delete a node.
Click Close to return to the Home page. The discovered nodes are displayed under Available Systems option in the left panel.
Right-click the node to display a menu and select Add to an Existing Management Group.
Enter the name of the management group.
Click Add to add the node to the group that you specified. The node is added to the management group.
